page.name: Pro Tips: Making Reading & Writing Matter
page.content:
1. Use case studies in your instruction. To introduce or conclude an instructional topic, adults may be engaged by a relevant situation (case) because they can then analyze that case to identify and practice applying potential solutions (study). We are using captioned video, along with access to a transcript, to support variability in all learners, whatever their context. Because they are real-life examples, case studies that include multiple options for perception further optimize relevance, value, and authenticity in learning (Engagement Principle: Checkpoint 7.2). 
  2. Get to know your AE learners' backgrounds. Understanding the background knowledge of your adult learners can help you tailor instruction to address each learner’s needs and connect their individual backgrounds to current content.  (Representation Principle : Checkpoint 3.1). 
  3. Model learning something new. It's not enough to tell learners how learning works, you need to show them. Make sure you showcase the struggle and the ways you "talk to" or encourage yourself as you are trying to accomplish a task. Demonstrate failing at a task and how you talk yourself through the perceived failure from a mastery-oriented perspective, using positive language that emphasizes the importance of practice over an innate or fixed ability (Engagement Principle: Checkpoint 8.4). 
  4. Use technology applications as scaffolds. Incorporate technology applications as scaffolds to meet the needs of all learners. Speech-to-Text: Some students are more confident in their speaking ability than in their writing ability. These apps empower students to tell their story without the barrier of having to write out their thoughts. This is also helpful to students with fine motor disabilities. Text-to-Speech: Students can type their story and have the text read back to them. This allows the learner to hear how their writing will sound to the reader (Representation Principle : Checkpoint 2.3 .
  5. Use prompts or sentence-starters. According to research, prompts elicit deeper engagement with instructional material. Providing prompts supports engagement by reducing the threats and distractions that some learners feel in response to open-ended questions, while also providing a tool for composition that support learners’ expression (Action & Expression Principle: Checkpoint 5.2).
